title: Grammar: Sentence Structure and Mechanics

vocab.definition: A group of words that contains a subject and a predicate
A group of words that works together but lacks a subject or predicate
Who or what the sentence is about
The part of the sentence that tells what the subject does or is
A sentence that joins two or more complete thoughts without proper punctuation
An incomplete sentence that is missing a subject or predicate
Words like 'and,' 'but,' and 'or' that connect equal parts of a sentence

teachingNotes: Practice identifying and fixing sentence errors. Use sentence combining activities. Emphasize the difference between phrases and clauses.

sample.question: What do we call a group of words with a subject and predicate?
A sentence without a subject or predicate is a ________.
A group of words without both subject and predicate is a ________.
What punctuation can separate two complete thoughts?
A ________ joins equal parts of a sentence.
Which word is NOT a coordinating conjunction?
What type of error is 'Running fast'?

truefalse.question: A phrase contains both a subject and a predicate.
A clause has a subject and predicate.
'Running through the park' is a complete sentence.
A run-on sentence needs proper punctuation.
Every fragment can stand alone as a sentence.
A comma alone can fix a run-on sentence.
Phrases work together as a unit in sentences.

multiplechoice.question: What is wrong with this sentence: 'Running through the park.'?
How can you fix: 'I read I write'?
Which is a phrase, not a clause?
Which fixes: 'I was tired I went to bed'?
choices: I was tired, I went to bed.
I was tired, so I went to bed.
I was tired I, went to bed.
I was tired I went, to bed.
expectedAny: I was tired, so I went to bed.
